@Richard Schaefer Fascinating, tell us more about these "sea bottom of coastal waters off the West Coast alone are littered with the remains of hundreds of Indian villages". The Little Ice Age (which was not a true ice age). It was a period of cooling that occurred after an especially massive tropical volcanic eruption in 1257, of the now-extinct Mount Samalas near Mount Rinjani, both in Lombok, Indonesia, followed by three smaller eruptions in 1268, 1275, and 1284. When a volcano erupts, its ash reaches high into the atmosphere and can spread to cover the whole earth. The ash cloud blocks out some of the incoming solar radiation, leading to worldwide cooling that can last up to two years after an eruption. Also emitted by eruptions is sulfur, in the form of sulfur dioxide gas. When it reaches the stratosphere, it turns into sulfuric acid particles, which reflect the sun's rays, further reducing the amount of radiation reaching Earth's surface. And again, the rest of your post is also nonsense.

As a climate scientist of sorts myself with a few publications I would say this:

1. anyone studying the science is impacted by momentum like that of a culture, a chemist is taught from day one to believe in the existence of electrons because that's a fundamental tenant upon which so much chemistry is based. If you as a chemist were to challenge that "we have it on the books" theory you would need a very large amount of evidence and would likely not be able to make an impact or even to get published if you HAD evidence. (you wouldn't even get funding to do the study in the first place so it would be pretty hard to get something off the ground). Keep in mind no one has "SEEN" an electron. Ever. It's a concept that explains a phenomenon.

2. scientists don't get paid very well. It's a saturated field like a lot of others in this information era and 90% make the same or less as a trucker or carpenter. It's a geek-out obsession for most. Funding is built on publish publish publish and you can only do that by writing something that builds off something someone else did. The "review" process isn't much more than a club where a few other "experts" breeze your paper and if you cited them (good for their funding) then they the gatekeepers let you pass and publish your paper (good for your funding). The object of the science in my opinion is less about finding truth as it is a business of publishing, although some researchers are genuinely interested and working hard to find truth they are <1%.

I'm wondering, why this story focuses so much on the 97% Consensus in the scientific community.
It's clear, that CO2 is a greenhouse gas. Our atmosphere consists of 0,0415% CO2, the Venus atmosphere consist of over 90% CO2. We have an average global temperature of about 16°C, Venus has an average temperature of over 450 °C.
The CO2-Level on earth has risen from about 280 ppm (parts per million) in the 1880s to 416 ppm now. And the level is climbing higher and higher every year. Global average temperature has risen since by about 1 °C. That is much faster than at the end of the last ice age. Nobody has found any natural reason for such a dramatic and fast change. That leaves us humans as the overwhelmingly single cause! Read the IPCC reports!

This is exactly the kind of low-resolution thinking, unproductive media that is holding society back from progress. Sources like these, critically evaluating the minutia of climate arguments are utterly useless to society, and harmful to cultural mindset. From what I gather, this video is arguing that not as many scientists agree that global warming is an urgent and man- made problem. I am, however, missing the point to that argument. Low resolution thinking fails to address the IMPLICATIONS of this reachy conclusion, and does not bring anybody into helpful action. If one is arguing, say that the environment is fine and the IMPLICATION of that is that we are a society should continue to support fossil fuels and environmental de-regulation, then that point should be stated.

Aside from principle, the content therein the argument is questionable. Even operating under the assumption that the majority of scientists did not think that this was a pressing issue and humans have had "limited" contribution (of which is entirely false if one does their own research), it makes no excuse for NOT striving for renewable energy and a cleaner planet. Even in the video it is unanimously agreed that pollution is a problem, CO2 is a harmful greenhouse gas, and that the climate is changing more rapidly than before. Given just these, why is it considered a negative thing to criticize and improve the actions of mankind? It is easy to see two arguments put plainly; the planet is not in danger and the harm we do to it does not have a significant impact and therefore no change should occur, or the planet is in danger in large because of humanity's impact and there is call for improvement of society to occur. It rather baffles me that arguments against improving society so that it is cleaner, healthier, and less harmful even exist. I am left only to wonder what agenda they adhere to, for it musn't surely be an agenda of productive righteousness and long term systems thinking. It would not be of a surprise to me if it is rather an agenda of short term, unsustainable monetary gain.

Seriously people, wake up. Think critically, and put ideas into a larger context. Media like this is shameful and although well produced, demonstrated a low-resolution thinking that is harmful to society. I will give that the call of the video was to discuss the "97%" and that was achieved, but the lack of foresight for implication renders this argument on parallel with that of a defensive child who's being threatened to have their toys removed.

@Dirk Digler 1) Atmospheric CO2 does seem to be higher as you describe. 2) There does seem to have been warming since Victorian times. (For instance the Thames had not frozen since 1814 except once in 1963 though parts of it just did again, whereas it froze regularly during the Little Ice Age.) But I reject the idea that we've measured that warming to a decimal place. How on Earth do we know the temperature of the Earth in 1880? Who was measuring it, how, where and how regularly? So 3) I dispute the claim that two-thirds of the warming has occurred since 1975. Indeed I claim that it is mathematically fatuous, because it amounts to saying that we know the Earth warmed by 0.26 degrees between 1880 and 1975 which is a rounding error not a measurement. And then that it warmed by 0.54 degrees since 1975. And again, I defy you to explain how we know the Earth's temperature even in 1975 to within a degree, let alone in 1934 or 1880 or 49 BC. Who was measuring it in Borneo, Irkutsk or the middle of the South Atlantic? 4) The "average rate of ice-age-recovery warming" is again something we just don't know. We know temperature did some strange stuff around the Younger Dryas, or think we do, rising and falling further and faster than anything we've seen in the thermometer era. But all of this stuff is built on claims to knowledge of the Earth's temperature going back a century and then 12k years that are completely and I would say rather obviously unfounded.

It's actually even worse, because what is claimed as "scientists have known since the mid 1800s", that CO2 is a 'greenhouse' gas and these "special" gases are why the Earth's surface is warmer than the Stephan Boltzmann predicts, is faulty as well. Contemporaries in physics dismissed the hypothesis as faulty -- you know, guys like James Maxwell.

The hypothesis was fully disproven by 1917 when Einstein published his famous 'The Quantum Theory of Radiation'. This groundbreaking paper mathematically demonstrated that the direction of molecules in motion must be considered for their absorptivity of light, as well as the momentum of the light itself. It predicted that if a gas molecule and an incident photon are moving in opposite directions, then it would be a violation of the Laws of Thermodynamics for that gas molecule to absorb the photon and increase in energy. Instead, Einstein surmised the concept of stimulated emission, that if the momentum of the gas molecule and incident light were in opposite directions, the interaction of the two would cause the gas molecule to emit two photons in the same direction as the incident light, thus cooling by that energy level instead of increasing. This was proven with the advent of the laser. The theory later led to the prediction that in a highly controlled experiment, light could cool gases to near absolute zero and create a new phase of matter which was dubbed Bose-Einstein condensate, which was later achieved in 1995. These factual demonstrations of Einstein's Quantum Theory of Radiation basically make it a law of physics, and trump the resurged back radiation hypothesis.

Tyndall's original experiments showing the absorptivity of certain gases to infrared light were done in tubes filled completely with those gases at far higher pressures than they naturally exist in the atmosphere. If you completely fill a tube with enough molecules of those gases, then the probabilities of certain wavelengths of incident light transmitting freely through those tubes reduces to near zero, and that is all Tyndall's experiments showed.
@Compassion Is Not for NPCs You're not fooling anyone buddy. Only a complete fool would argue that CO2 is not a greenhouse gas.

@Frank Smith That's not what the second law states so I am baffled who you are quoting. That was not my argument at all and you clearly didn't understand it. I didn't bother reading the rest of your reply because I see no point.

@Compassion Is Not for NPCs The second law of thermodynamics states "Heat generally cannot flow spontaneously from a material at lower temperature to a material at higher temperature." So if you put something hot next to something cold, the hot thing won't get hotter, and the cold thing won't get colder. So,skeptics tells us that, because the air, including the greenhouse gasses, is cooler than the surface of the Earth, it cannot warm the Earth. If it did, they say, that means heat would have to flow from cold to hot, in apparent violation of the second law of thermodynamics. The skeptic is ignoring the fact that the Earth is being warmed by the sun, which makes all the difference. Now consider the blanket that keeps you warm. If your skin feels cold, wrapping yourself in a blanket can make you warmer. Why? Because your body is generating heat, and that heat is escaping from your body into the environment. When you wrap yourself in a blanket, the loss of heat is reduced, some is retained at the surface of your body, and you warm up. You get warmer because the heat that your body is generating cannot escape as fast as before. If you put the blanket on a tailors dummy, which does not generate heat, it will have no effect. The dummy will not spontaneously get warmer. The heat always flows from warm to cold – just more or less effectively. The processes of heat transfer are quite different – for the blanket it is mainly heat conduction, for the greenhouse effect it is thermal radiation. The climate deniers claim that the colder atmosphere cannot radiate thermal radiation towards the warmer surface. This is of course nonsense. The cool Earth also sends thermal radiation towards the hot sun – how would thermal radiation leaving Earth know how warm the surface is that it’s going to hit? It’s just that the sun sends more radiation back to us – the net flow is from hot to cold. More is not implied by the second law of thermodynamics.

@M McGahn One of the first projections of future warming came from John Sawyer at the UK’s Met Office in 1973. In a paper published in Nature in 1973, he hypothesised that the world would warm 0.6C between 1969 and 2000, and that atmospheric CO2 would increase by 25%. Sawyer argued for a climate sensitivity – how much long-term warming will occur per doubling of atmospheric CO2 levels – of 2.4C, which is not too far off the best estimate of 3C used by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) today. So as you can see climate science goes way back before the green new deal. Would you like more examples?

@mark y The 400 years of sun spot observations gives us a proxy on solar activity. The Little Ice Age coincided with the Maunder Minimum of the sun where virtually no sunspots were counted for 50 years and the decades surrounding it were also relatively weak. Solar activity increased slightly but became relatively very active over the time of observations in just the last century, from 1920-2011, this is called the Modern Maximum. It was just the last solar cycle, #24, that was relatively weak but still as active as 1880-1920. Expecting immediate cooling from just 11 years of relatively lower solar activity is like expecting a freight train to come to a stop immediately if the power is decreased to the wheels. But it is more complicated than that, because a freight train's speed is a simple linear system mostly dependent on the energy turning the wheels, whereas the climate is among the most complex dynamic systems we have ever studied. Ocean cycles have oscillations and cycles of decades to millennium, not to mention the hundreds of other variables all in play. A short period of warming or cooling in a complex dynamic system therefore cannot be easily explained by just contemporary changes in variables - climate is a non linear system with variables spanning thousands of years. Here's an example of a linear system and then the complexity of adding just ONE more variable to the system: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U39RMUzCjiU

Easy, they keep changing their story when they get themselves into a corner. First, there was global warming with intentionally manipulated data. Yep, false! Then, global cooling. Nah, false. Uh oh. Then, climate change. But wait, climate has been changing since the beginning of time. No, no, its climate change due to humans. How so? Oh, greenhouse gases you say. Which ones? Oh CO2, that makes up .05%, is a small fraction of the greenhouse gases that is good for plants, and the one that actually LAGS the historical temperature changes in the atmosphere. Oh, that one. So, to be clear, man can have ultimate sway over the cosmos (earth's orbits, earth's tilt & seasons, solar outputs, cosmic radiation, solar storms, etc.) and govern climate change... yeh, somehow, I just don't think so.

@Craig Rawlings Without carbon dioxide (CO2) the terrestrial greenhouse would collapse and plunge Earth into an icebound state. Today, the average temperature is +15C. Within 50 years the average temperature would drop to -21C without the warming provided by atmospheric carbon dioxide. The delicate link between the planet's temperature and carbon dioxide has also been proved by geologic records of CO2 levels during ice ages and interglacial periods. The temperature difference between an ice age period and an interglacial period is only 5°C. During previous ice ages, CO2 levels were near 180 parts per million (ppm). During the warm interglacial periods the levels were near 280 ppm. Today we are living in an interglacial period that started 12,000 years ago and may last another 40,000 years. Scientists continue to worry that, as CO2 levels approach 400 ppm, we are in uncharted territory with no historical precedent as far back as 1 million years.

@chris m Here is what science tells us. Current atmospheric concentrations of CO2 are about 30% higher than they were about 150 years ago at the dawn of the industrial revolution. Before the industrial revolution, the CO2 content in the air remained quite steady for thousands of years. Natural CO2 is not static, however. It is generated by natural processes, and absorbed by others. But consider what happens when more CO2 is released from outside of the natural carbon cycle – by burning fossil fuels. Although our output of 29 gigatons of CO2 is tiny compared to the 750 gigatons moving through the carbon cycle each year, it adds up because the land and ocean cannot absorb all of the extra CO2. About 40% of this additional CO2 is absorbed. The rest remains in the atmosphere, and as a consequence, atmospheric CO2 is at its highest level in millions of years. (A natural change of 100ppm normally takes 5,000 to 20,000 years. The recent increase of has taken just 120 years).

This is an excellent video. My own recollection of the claim about the 97% Consensus is this:

A decade or two ago, some global warming alarmist floated the comment that "97% of all scientists believe in global warming." The comment was made in the frivolous manner that one person might make at a party; something like "Oh everybody loves it."

As the frivolous comment got passed around by alarmist, the deniers rebuked the comment for what it was, simply an exaggerated off-the-cuff remark with no foundation. I was one of these deniers. On the denier side, we had an actual petition signed by over 30,000 "scientists" who stated their opposition to the claim of man-made global warming/cooling. (SEE: http://www.petitionproject.org)

I always used this petition in this way: "If there are 30,000 scientists who have signed their names in disagreement, where is the document with 970,000 scientists who claim that man-made climate change is happening?" Needless to say, no one ever came forth with such a document.

To try to validate the 97% claim, alarmists then tried other tactics to make the claim accurate. One such study was an online search for published articles (or all types) that mentioned the words or term "climate change" ad perhaps "global warming." If I remember correctly, there were about 10,000 results. The results weren't all "papers" as in scientific study papers, many were just articles and editorials. The results fell in three categories: Those items that agree with "climate change," those that didn't agree with "climate change," and those that didn't offer any opinion (they just reported on the argument). A very large part of the results fell in the "no opinion" category. Another large part fell in the "agree" category, and a small part of the results fell in the "deny or disagree" category.

The "researchers" who put the online search together disqualified the results that offered no specific opinion one way or the other - they just reported on the argument. They then further massaged the results a bit to remove some results because they claimed they weren't from "scientific" people or entities. These "researchers" were able to now say that about 90% or a little higher were agreeing that climate change was real. However, in reporting this study, and using it to try to validate the generalized 97% consensus, the "researchers" stated that the study was based on 10,000 results in order to give their claim some weight.

The actual numbers were something like 52% of all the results were of the opinion that "man-made climate change" was real; 5-10% of the results were of the opinion that there was "no man-made climate change;" and roughly 40% expressed no opinion one way or the other. I would agree that if 52% of all published scientific papers claimed that the phenomenon is real that it is an interesting statistic to note.

However, there's a few significant problems with this. Firstly, 52% is not 97%, and it represents a far greater difference of opinion than the alarmists would like the world to know. Second, the argument to be made is the argument that "man-made climate change is happening." Therefore the greatest amount of papers/editorials/articles to be written and published would come from people who have something to gain by popularizing the event. The vast majority of the community would have nothing to gain and therefore would not go out of their way to write a paper/editorial/article that denies climate change; they would simply stand on the historic and scientific fact that climate is cyclical. And third, "consensus" is not proof or facts. For instance, water doesn't boil at sea level at 212 degrees F (100 C) because of scientific consensus, it boils at that temperature because that is the effect that occurs when water is actually and factually heated to 212 F. The 52% consensus would still have to prove that the climate is unnaturally changing, that it is changing because of man-made actions, and that the actions will result in some type of unusual catastrophic result. As of today, there is no scientific proof that of any of this, there is simply conjecture.

In further support of my position I submit these items for your perusal:
https://www.forbes.com/sites/peterferrara/2013/11/12/the-coming-revelation-of-the-global-warming-fraud-resembles-the-obamacare-lie/?sh=570ecf6d35c9

https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamestaylor/2013/05/30/global-warming-alarmists-caught-doctoring-97-percent-consensus-claims/?sh=642a92d485dd

@Frank Smith As is quite common, it is not mentioned what happened between 2000 and 2020. Usually it is not mentioned because the models have trouble with this time period. (Often leading to suggestions of non-linear release of ocean heat.) The difficulty lies not in that one person's prediction differs between 3.0 and 2.6, it is whether or not the effect measured was due to that or other factors. Other factors might have produced the warming. If a normal peak is 300ppm, and we are a little over 400ppm, then the actual increase is 33.3%. (And we are near the end of a 100,000 year cycle where a peak is expected.) In any case, one would not like to think of the effect of doubling the CO2, which oscillates between 175 and 300 ppm over vast time scales, but is shockingly high right now. Be aware that the measurements of CO2 from long ago are less accurate than measurements taken over the few hundred years we have had direct equipment. (As opposed to ice cores, etc.) I find it interesting, but not at all unusual, to find the CO2 has similar cycles to global temperatures. It might lead one to conclude that there is a feedback loop where warmer temperatures cause plant life to convert more O2, and colder temperatures reduce the plant conversion to increase the CO2, having a regulatory effect. I would guess we should reduce cutting down forests, particularly without any replacement policy. What worries me is if those of us in more developed countries are using a period of warming to justify restrictions which would preclude less developed countries from catching up. This is why I am sensitive to the political aspect being so divergent from the scientific. We have no way of knowing right now if the cooling starting in 2000 is the 100,000 year cycle coming to and end, which would argue that AGW is abated, but much worse, or if it is an oscillation due to underdamped response, and thus AGW is trivial.

@Steve Grant You are both ignorant and overblown. I do mathematical modeling as part of my job and am intricately familiar with both the modeling and the solution engines which compute them. That is why I am critical of the process because I do understand very clearly how modeling works. They do provide a wide range of estimates, and if you look back at the decades of modelling what I see from the data is that the estimates that track performance with minimal error predict little warming from human produced greenhouse gasses, and those that have large errors do predict it. In fact, overpredict it. Both sides of the debate use skewed data and selected results to bolster their extreme positions. While there is a political consensus, there is no scientific consensus since most of the 97% number is fantasy. The survey was self-selective, and most of the respondents did not take the extreme position. Of the few climate scientists who responded, most are funded to produce global warming results. What I focus on are the models used to predict climate for risk assessment such as crops (too much or too little rain), extreme weather, etc. where the person is paid to produce accurate results, and gets paid less when they are wrong. I truly do not have a political bias; if the most accurate models predicted a huge effect I would simply say so. The fact that quite a few individuals have positioned themselves to make billions off climate change extremism, particularly off 'cap and trade', does concern me since wealth corrupts science all the time. In fact, the warming trend reversed in the 2000s, and has oscillated since then. If you look at the plots it seems as if the 100,000 year cycle is coming near the 10,000 cycle and there is a chance of another little ice age. I feel it is this transition phase that is causing a great deal of problems since it seems to oscillate. This is referred to as an underdamped system. Another concern is whether the models produce this underdamped response, or whether the simulation engine is not tuned correctly. This latter effect happens quite often and there are people who get false simulation results, but it is the result they were hoping for, and do not dig into the convergence/fit issues.

@Vlad Impaler One of the first projections of future warming came from John Sawyer at the UK’s Met Office in 1973. In a paper published in Nature in 1973, he hypothesised that the world would warm 0.6C between 1969 and 2000, and that atmospheric CO2 would increase by 25%. Sawyer argued for a climate sensitivity – how much long-term warming will occur per doubling of atmospheric CO2 levels – of 2.4C, which is not too far off the best estimate of 3C used by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) today.

@JimTheHammerXCIII The way that we know that fossil fuel burning and land clearing specifically are responsible for the increase in CO2 in the last 150 years is through the measurement of carbon isotopes. Isotopes are simply different atoms with the same chemical behavior but with different masses. Carbon is composed of three different isotopes, 14C, 13C and 12C. 12C is the most common. 13C is about 1% of the total. 14C accounts for only about 1 in 1 trillion carbon atoms. CO2 produced from burning fossil fuels or burning forests has quite a different isotopic composition from CO2 in the atmosphere. This is because plants have a preference for the lighter isotopes (12C vs. 13C); thus they have lower 13C/12C ratios. Since fossil fuels are ultimately derived from ancient plants, plants and fossil fuels all have roughly the same 13C/12C ratio – about 2% lower than that of the atmosphere. As CO2 from these materials is released into, and mixes with, the atmosphere, the average 13C/12C ratio of the atmosphere decreases.

@RedwoodTheElf Recent research has uncovered evidence for lower ocean temperatures during the Ordovician than previously thought, creating ideal conditions for a huge spurt in marine biodiversity and correspondingly large drawdown of CO2 from the atmosphere through carbon burial in the ocean. A period of mountain-building was also underway (the so-called Taconic orogeny) increasing the amount of rock weathering taking place and subsequently lowering CO2 levels even further. The evidence is definitely there for a short-term disruption of the carbon cycle. Another important factor is the sun. During the Ordovician, it would have been several percent dimmer according to established nuclear models of main sequence stars. Surprisingly, this raises the CO2 threshold for glaciation to a staggering 3000 ppmv or so. This also explains (along with the logarithmic forcing effect of CO2) why a runaway greenhouse didn't occur: with a dimmer sun, high CO2 is necessary to stop the Earth freezing over. In summary, we know CO2 was probably very high coming into the Late Ordovician period, however the subsequent dip in CO2 was brief enough not to register in the GEOCARB model, yet low enough (with the help of a dimmer sun) to trigger permanent ice-formation. Effectively it was a brief excursion to coldness during an otherwise warm era, due to a coincidence of conditions.

It seems obvious that the opinion expressed about "the best research" is totally unqualified. The underlying hypothesis/presumptions per global warming is that CO2 emitted by mankind (less than 4% of the CO2 generated by "Mother Earth") is raising the planet's temperature . . . with further stipulations that relative humidity does not change and neither does the sun's energy output. Such assumptions are indefensible. The "Achilles heel" of the CO2 'pivot' is that the data sets proposing to show that global warming is occurring and being caused by CO2 have been “adjusted”, “homogenized”, "parameterized" and “normalized”. @kNews & kNotes The second law of thermodynamics states "Heat generally cannot flow spontaneously from a material at lower temperature to a material at higher temperature." So if you put something hot next to something cold, the hot thing won't get hotter, and the cold thing won't get colder. So,skeptics tells us that, because the air, including the greenhouse gasses, is cooler than the surface of the Earth, it cannot warm the Earth. If it did, they say, that means heat would have to flow from cold to hot, in apparent violation of the second law of thermodynamics. The skeptic is ignoring the fact that the Earth is being warmed by the sun, which makes all the difference. Now consider the blanket that keeps you warm. If your skin feels cold, wrapping yourself in a blanket can make you warmer. Why? Because your body is generating heat, and that heat is escaping from your body into the environment. When you wrap yourself in a blanket, the loss of heat is reduced, some is retained at the surface of your body, and you warm up. You get warmer because the heat that your body is generating cannot escape as fast as before. If you put the blanket on a tailors dummy, which does not generate heat, it will have no effect. The dummy will not spontaneously get warmer. The heat always flows from warm to cold – just more or less effectively. The processes of heat transfer are quite different – for the blanket it is mainly heat conduction, for the greenhouse effect it is thermal radiation. The climate deniers claim that the colder atmosphere cannot radiate thermal radiation towards the warmer surface. This is of course nonsense. The cool Earth also sends thermal radiation towards the hot sun – how would thermal radiation leaving Earth know how warm the surface is that it’s going to hit? It’s just that the sun sends more radiation back to us – the net flow is from hot to cold. More is not implied by the second law of thermodynamics. And when you talk of Earths irregular orbit you are talking about the Milankovitch cycles. Earth's orbit around the sun is not fixed. It varies in its distance from the sun (eccentricity), the angle of the earth's rotation (obliquity)and the earth's wobble (precession). You can google "the Milankovitch cycles" for more info. Isn't science fascinating? The Milankovitch cycles drive the ice ages but his takes thousands of years. This in no way explains the rapid warming the Earth is now seeing. As the Earth moved out of ice ages over the past million years, the global temperature rose a total of 4 to 7 degrees Celsius over about 5,000 years. In the past century alone, the temperature has climbed 0.7 degrees Celsius, roughly ten times faster than the average rate of ice-age-recovery warming.

@Frank Smith That all 42 models of (Catastrophic) Anthropogenic Global Warming have failed is largely because of the hypothesis/assumption that atmospheric gases heat the planet, which violates the second law of thermodynamics. While atmospheric gases (of which CO2 is less than 4%) are trapping radiation that emanates from the planet, they can’t and don't send it back into the planet. The most they can do is warm the air a bit, something akin to attempting to warm a bathtub full of water with (as many as you want) portable room heaters. Irrefutably, the greenhouse effect of CO2 is logarithmic, not linear or exponential. Hence it is only possible for CO2 to increase global warming by perhaps another 0.2 degrees Celsius, no matter how much higher the concentration of the trace gas, carbon dioxide. The big drivers of climate change are all the types of radiative energy from the sun . . . affecting ocean currents, the jet stream, and the like. The sun itself is more than 7000 times more potent than any effect carbon dioxide could conceivably have, even though the sun's energy output varies considerably. Notably it is now in a Grand Solar Minimum, its lowest energy output in two centuries. The GSM, in addition to Earth's irregular orbit taking us many tens of thousands of miles farther away from our primary energy source, is indicative of historic patterns that cycled our planet into a glacial episode . . . this would be the 19th of the last 7500 years.

@kNews & kNotes CO2 is a greenhouse gas, and the simple truth is greenhouse gases allow short wavelength solar radiation to pass through the atmosphere unimpeded. As the Sun warms up Earth’s surface, longer wavelength thermal radiation is reflected back into the atmosphere. Some of this thermal radiation passes into space, some of the radiation is absorbed and some is reflected back to Earth. More CO2 means more thermal radiation is reflected back to Earth and this causes the temperature on Earth to rise. It is all explained through science.

OK, here's a chunk of a reading I give my university classes. 5) OK, but how does more CO2 in the air make the Earth warmer? The average temperature of the Earth is around 59 degrees Fahrenheit, but if there were no greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane, the Earth’s average temperature would drop to around zero (Fahrenheit). But how exactly do more carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases make the Earth warmer? All day every day, the Earth is bombarded with light energy from the sun. Not all of it reaches the surface, but when it does, that light energy gets transformed into heat energy or infrared radiation. It you have ever stood barefoot on a blacktop surface on a hot summer day, you can feel how that light energy has been transformed into lots of heat. But heat rises, so that heat or thermal energy starts to rise higher and higher, heading for outer space. But the air is filled with lots of molecules, and in every cubic meter of air there are molecules of CO2 floating around. If thermal energy of the right wavelengths hits a CO2 molecule, that molecule absorbs that heat energy but re-radiates that energy in all directions. So now, instead of all that heat rising straight towards outer space, most of it has been re-radiated outwards from the molecule in a different direction—some upwards but not straight up, some sideways, some downwards, and only a tiny amount straight up. This process, repeated over and over again as thermal energy encounters CO2 molecules as it rises towards space, slows down the loss of heat from the sun to outer space. Holding that heat in the atmosphere longer makes it warmer than Earth would be otherwise. Thus, adding more CO2 to the atmosphere is like adding a blanket to your bed on a cold night—the blanket makes you warmer not by creating its own heat but by keeping the heat from your body closer to your body for longer. 6) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the lower atmosphere and the oceans got warmer than before—just as the theory of man-made global warming predicted they would. (see the links after #13) 7) Furthermore, after human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the upper atmosphere got cooler—just as the theory of man-made global warming predicted it would. This happens because the additional CO2 we added is now trapping more of that heat in the lower atmosphere. (see the links after #13) 8) Moreover, after human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there was an increase in the lower atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate (which slows the escape of heat to the atmosphere and makes the Earth warmer). Again, this was just what the theory of man-made global warming predicted would happen. (see the links after #13) 9) In parallel, as human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there was a decrease in the upper atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate. This was just what the theory of man-made global warming predicted would happen. (see the links after #13) 10) Despite a massive and well-funded propaganda campaign and widespread misinformation about this point, many models of the relationship between levels of greenhouse gases and average global temperatures have predicted how much additional CO2 would cause how much additional global warming with impressive accuracy. The models work. https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-how-well-have-climate-models-projected-global-warming https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1029/2019GL085378 11) Research that takes into consideration the effects of multiple natural factors (sun’s activity, earth’s orbit, etc.) and anthropogenic (man-made) factors on global temperatures has found that the addition of greenhouse gases due to burning fossil fuels caused all or virtually of recent net warming, whether you go back 20 years, 40 years, 60 years, 100 years, or 150 years. To put it differently, over any time span you choose to go back from now, if it were not for human activity, the Earth would have either cooled slightly, stayed the same temperature, or for a few time spans, warmed just a tiny bit. A chart on Wikipedia’s web page illustrates clearly how the effect of natural drivers on global temperatures is overwhelmed by the effects of human drivers of global temperatures: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_warming 12) Contrary to misinformation from AGW (anthropogenic global warming) skeptics, SEVEN different articles have all found that 90% or more of practicing climate scientists agree that human activity is significantly warming the planet. See all three levels of information: https://skepticalscience.com/global-warming-scientific-consensus.htm The scientists most likely to deny man-made global warming and climate disruption are those whose paychecks depend on us continuing to burn fossil fuels (e.g., geologists working for oil companies) or people whose political beliefs make it difficult to face the economic consequences of admitting that man-made global warming is real and a serious threat: https://skepticalscience.com/Geologists-climate-change-denial.html 13) Taken together, ALL those pieces of evidence prove conclusively that recent warming was caused by humans burning fossil fuels (and other greenhouse-gas producing activities [deforestation, cement production]). In terms of climate science, evidence that strong is like investigating a murder scene and knowing the suspect had motive, opportunity, plus you know the means of death, the suspect’s fingerprints are on the murder weapon and you have a videotape of him committing the crime. All or virtually all recent warming and climate disruption is due to human activities that increased the levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere (burning fossil fuels, deforestation, making cement) and that reduced the Earth’s ability to sequester carbon (deforestation). All you have to do is look at the equation for the water mixing calculator to know that man made climate change is completely false. The mixing of two volumes of water requires two exact volumes of water with one volume being 4 degrees hotter than the other to raise the temperature of the resulting volume by 2 degrees. The same rise in temperature of the global warming trend. If you notice, the resulting rise can only be changed by a volume EQUAL to the original volume.

Now, let's look at the increase in volume of carbon dioxide in our atmosphere since the beginning of the industrial revolution. It's gone from 280 PPM to 400 PPM. or 0.022% of the original volume.That's 4,545 times smaller that the volume of the atmosphere. Which means that, according to our water mixture calculator there is NO WAY that increase in carbon dioxide could have the slightest effect on global temperatures. Also, for you chemistry and physics geniuses, we know that water transfers heat far better than air, so the effect is even less that the asserted water mixture calculator.

What I've read is, Water vapor and greenhouse gases, absorb IR photons sending most of them back into space cooling the earth by reducing the sun's heat that is able to make it to the earth's surface.

https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/features/EnergyBalance/page6.php

"Just as the major atmospheric gases (oxygen and nitrogen) are transparent to incoming sunlight, they are also transparent to outgoing thermal infrared. However, water vapor, carbon dioxide, methane, and other trace gases are opaque to many wavelengths of thermal infrared energy." "When greenhouse gas molecules absorb thermal infrared energy, their temperature rises. Like coals from a fire that are warm but not glowing, greenhouse gases then radiate an increased amount of thermal infrared energy in ALL DIRECTIONS". "Because greenhouse gas molecules radiate heat in ALL DIRECTIONS, some of it spreads downward and ultimately comes back into contact with the Earth’s surface, where it is absorbed. The temperature of the surface becomes warmer than it would be if it were heated only by direct solar heating. This supplemental heating of the Earth’s surface by the atmosphere is the natural greenhouse effect." Up high or down low, I don't see any difference if NASA is correct. At the height of the Atmosphere, the Earth constitutes 1/3rd of the space. So the IR absorbed by the ghg, both for incoming sun heat and emitted Earth heat, will be absorbed then emitted in "all directions". 1/3rd will hit the Earth below and the other 2/3rds will go into space. Of the Earth emitted heat, 1/3rd of that will be absorbed by the ghgs going out, and sent back to the earth adding additional warming to the earth, this warming is the greenhouse effect according to NASA. So, water vapor and the ghgs, cool the earth by blocking out 66.4% of Sun heat, while keeping in only 11% (1/3rd of 1/3rd). The atmosphere keeps out six times more heat than it keeps in. If we add more molecules of CO2 they will absorb more entering sun heat and cool the earth more than they do now. With the earth getting less heat, there will be less heat to keep in, so the GHE should fall. I don't see how, if NASA is correct, we can be warming the planet by adding more CO2 to the atmosphere.

@Shaun Sharted We always encourage people to link to relevant data or analysis in the interest of informed discussion. Speaking of which, how would a study "disprove" anthropogenic climate change? If you suggest that there are no studies showing ample evidence of natural climate variability, including as large as that between the Little Ice Age and the present, you are misinformed. If you suggest that they have no relevance to the question of whether current changes are at least in part natural, you are confused.

I'm not a 'climatologist' but I have reasonably high qualifications in fluid mechanics (or hydraulics as it's also known). This is the study of liquids and gasses and how they interact. I've looked at quite a lot of papers on AGW and the common theme seems to be 'statistical modelling' and interpolation. The sample bases are so small (0.0001% for CO2) in the ecosphere (which is a non-homogeneous material) and it's very poor scientific practice to interpolate the 99.9999% missing data. I'm not denying AGW, but I do deny that AGW is 'proven' and the 'science is settled'. At best, it's a hypothesis based on the statistical analysis of very scant data.

SkepticalScience, a blog spearheaded by climate science “consensus” advocate John Cook, is widely considered the explanatory guidebook for the anthropogenic global warming movement.

The blog claims that CO2 molecules collectively function similar to that of a blanket, in reducing the rate at which the human body cools down. The rate or time-lapse involved in this “slowing” of heat loss, however, is problematic to the paradigm that says CO2 drives global warming.

Going technical for a minute, Professor Nasif Nahle has discovered that the “mean free path” for a quantum wave to pass through the atmosphere before colliding with a CO2 molecule is about 33 meters (Nahle, 2011a), and such a wide gap between molecular collisions hardly conjures-up the image of CO2 functioning like a blanket.

And even more saliently, Nahle has mathematically assessed that the rate at which CO2 molecules can retain heat at the surface may only last about 0.0001 of a second (Nahle, 2011b) — meaning that the atmospheric CO2 concentration, whether it be 300 PPM or 400 PPM, effectively doesn’t matter — the time-lapse differential would be immaterial for either concentration.

Consequently, Nahle has concluded that “carbon dioxide has not an effect on climate changes or warming periods on the Earth” and his work has been endorsed by the Faculty of Physics of the University of Nuevo Leon (Mexico).

Temperature cannot be measured directly, it is an inferred measurement dependent upon the effect of heat on a substance. Comparison of temperatures today to those 200 years ago is scientifically invalid since the same thermometers are not being used for each measurement. In addition, thermometers of the 19th century are subject to inaccuracies not common to today's digital instruments. Finally, the calibration methods and standards have also changed over that time period. Therefore, claims of "warming" are without scientific proof, since the means of measurement cannot be validated.

If you pour into the results, the actual data, not just the summaries or catchy headlines, this is essentially what you find. These are the facts as we understand them - sea levels are rising and will very likely continue to rise between 3 and 15 meters, going by historical data.
There is likely little we can do to prevent this - its going to happen regardless of human interaction, but there are indications humans are increasing the speed at which it will happen.
The impact of human interaction is still debated, we just don't have enough data to make a concrete conclusion and thus the time frame is speculation.

There is no right answer to how much should we spend, or how should we spend this money, to mitigate, prevent, or prepare for climate change. I dont have an answer to fiscal policy and, in all honesty, most of the "spend money to solve climate change" plans I see governments doing seem misguided.

Mark Twain never said that. You have been fooled. This channel does not allow links to be posted, so I am going to copy-paste here one of the articles on this quote, this one is from Snopes dot com: ______________________________________________________ Did Mark Twain Say ‘It’s Easier to Fool People Than to Convince Them That They Have Been Fooled’? While the quote "it's easier to fool people than to convince them that they have been fooled" is often attributed to Mark Twain, there's no evidence that the author actually wrote this phrase. Dan Evon Published 29 December 2016 Claim Mark Twain said that it's easier to fool people than to convince them that they have been fooled. Rating Unproven Origin A quote frequently attributed to Mark Twain gained greater prominence in 2016 as media publications debated the effect of “fake news” on the internet: It’s easier to fool people than to convince them that they have been fooled. The quote shown here has been attributed to Mark Twain (or Samuel Clemens, if you prefer) by dozens of web sites, books, and memes, and was even available on a T-shirt sold by Amazon. However, none of these sources provided any information about where or when Twain allegedly said this. Was it written or spoken? Did it appear in a book or a newspaper article? A lack of source information for this particular quote is especially noteworthy, because Mark Twain’s writing was very well-documented. Several volumes of quotes from the author of _Huckleberry Finn_ have been compiled, yet we were unable to find this quote in any of them. Barbara Schmidt, who operates TwainQuotes . com, told us that she also had no evidence that Twain wrote or uttered this phrase. However, Schmidt directed us to a passage from the _Autobiography of Mark Twain, Volume 2,_ in which he expressed a similar opinion about the power of a lie:: The general idea of that quote (although not that wording) is one Mark Twain expressed in regard to lying — in that is it hard to convince people they have been a victim of a lie. He did state: “The glory which is built upon a lie soon becomes a most unpleasant incumbrance. … How easy it is to make people believe a lie, and how hard it is to undo that work again!” – Autobiographical dictation, 2 December 1906. Published in _Autobiography of Mark Twain, Volume 2_ (University of California Press, 2013) The full quote, which can be viewed via The Mark Twain Project, reads as follows (emphasis ours): _The truth is, I did not have to wait long to get tired of my triumphs. Not thirty days, I think. _*_The glory which is built upon [a] lie soon becomes a most unpleasant incumbrance._*_ No doubt for a while I enjoyed having my exploits told and retold and told again [in my presence] and wondered over and exclaimed about, but I quite distinctly remember that there presently came a time [when] the subject was wearisome [and odious] to me and I could not endure the disgusting discomfort of [it.] I am well aware that the world-glorified doer of a deed of great and real splendor has just my experience; I know that he deliciously enjoys hearing about it for three or four weeks, and that pretty soon after that he begins to dread the mention of it, and by and by wishes he had been with the damned before he ever thought of doing that deed; I remember how [General Sherman used to rage and swear [over] “When we were marching through Georgia,”] which was played at him and sung at him everywhere he went; still, I think I suffered a shade more than the legitimate hero does, he being privileged to soften his misery with the reflection that his glory was at any rate golden and reproachless in its origin, whereas I had no such privilege, there being no possible way to make mine respectable._ *_How easy it is to make people believe a lie, and [how] hard it is to undo that work again!_*_ [Thirty-five years after those evil exploits of mine I visited my old mother, whom I had not seen for ten years]; and being moved by what seemed to me a rather noble and perhaps [page 303] heroic impulse, I thought I would humble myself and confess my ancient fault. It cost me a great effort to make up my mind; I dreaded the sorrow that would rise in her face, and the shame that would look out of her eyes; but after long and troubled reflection, the sacrifice seemed due and right, and I gathered my resolution together and made the confession._ It is possible that someone else paraphrased Twain’s words, and others conflated both the actual phrase and the paraphrase over time. However, we have been unable to find evidence that Twain spoke or wrote this exact phrase.

@David Davison Look at the hockey stick graph. Do you even remember what it looks like? It shows a gradually decreasing average temperature between the medieval warm period until the little ice age, then it shoots up around 1900. The medieval warm period was local to Europe, and whether it shows up significantly on graphs depends a lot on where recordings are taken from. Parts of Africa being drier does not mean they were warmer - in fact, the opposite is most likely true, as cooler temperatures result in less evaporation and therefore lower humidity (Antarctica is the biggest desert in the world for a reason). Japan and Chile were also relatively warm during the medieval warm period, but other places (such as Australia) were much colder during the medieval warm period than immediately before or after it.

@David Davison It becomes apparent when you look at what the thesis is. Vaguely citing here: Of the papers that took any stance at all, 97% agreed that humans are one of the major influences on the current climate change. Anyone who disagrees with the existence of this consensus is absolutely free to do their own study. It's been 7 years and none have been released. Also, on a less scientific approach as to the consensus: have you heard of the movement "scientists for future"? It's basically the academic arm of Fridays for future. Last year, a petition was launched, which only verified scientists from the broader fields of climate-related sciences were allowed to sign. You had to deliver proof that you work in this field. Last time I checked, early into the launch, which was around February 2019, they had already gathered more than 14.000 signatures. 2 reasons why I have no doubts about the general consensus in the field. As I said, I went into this with a completely open mind. I would be extremely happy to learn that nothing we do is detrimental to our planet or future. Of course I could be wrong and I'm completely open to that idea. So far, after many a discussion and countless hours if reading, I have no reason to believe the consensus is wrong.

For both abstract ratings and authors’ self-ratings, the percentage of endorsements among papers expressing a position on AGW marginally increased over time. As a relatively liberal, politically centre-left person who's folllowed the climate debate fairly closely for over a decade - this video is, in many ways, quite legitimate and raises significant problems in the reporting of data like this.

Whoever has said that "97% of scientists agree it's man-made and extremely dangerous" is butchering the actual meaning of the surveys that were done and this video makes that clear. As the primary speaker with the plaid shirt says, the people reporting that are overwhelmingly not going to be trained scientists of statisticians because the survey didn't find all those sentiments from the same 97% and to present otherwise is innacurate and deceptive.

However, for the narrator lady to then sum up that
1)" 'most' experts agree that carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas "
2) "and probably causes SOME warming"
3) "human activity has SOME impact on climate, probably including SOME warning"

- all seem like very incautious or deliberately misleading language, not least because it's unclear how she chooses the 'experts' she includes:

1): Given the soft, squishy sound of 'most', this is a worrying word to use to describe how many agree on the elementary idea that CO2 is a greenhouse gas - it's exact, precise level of impact (including by comparison to others like water or methane) may be debated, but the idea that it's not a GH gas at all is very hard to find represented credibly.

Futher to the language aspect I just came from a video called 'cimate scientist takes on room full of sceptics' where the scientist talks 29:30mins about the vital importance of strictly defining terms like "Likely" given that different people have WILDLY different interpretations of the meaning:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6hCRafyV0zI
(see @29:30mins, for his work researching and defining stats-language, but I also recommend the video for explaining the scientific response to many common concerns held by sceptics)

2) again, "SOME" is dangerous language here, the numerical meaining of which will be influenced by linguistics and existing beliefs. The dictionary def of some is 'an unspecified amount or number of.' - which means the narrator takes no specific view, when actually this is another field where the substantial majority agree it's a major contributor, certainly not minor, even if exact numbers are debated.

3) "Some" (once again) is now used to describe the impact of ALL human activity, which includes effects like CO2, methane from global farming, manmade aerosols (which have a cooling effect) as well as mass deforestation and land clearance. To imply that all these massive scale actions merely have 'some' impact is, again, alarmingly far from reality. Perhaps the authors didn't consider some of these less hot-topic factors, and maybe they factored in their vaguely-stated (again, the language used isn't helpful) conclusions/doubts about CO2's role as it barely had any...

Furthermore, when the host talks about the smearing of dissenting voices amongst the scientific community, there are problems with this claim too - Skeptics across the board may well be unfairly vilified - anyone can see that these are uncivil times for politicised discourse, and in the video I linked, both the sceptical audience and the climate scientist describe experiences of death-threats and abuse they have received - so this nastiness does fly both ways - but the scientific community themselves will only truly discredit those who's science, and advocacy of that science, does not hold up to scrutiny or who's impact is greatly misnterpretted or overstated in significance to the other factors and research.

Bear in mind that climate scientists THEMSELVES are constantly 'dissenting' by re-checking their and their peers assumptions, critically reviewing the conclusions of their peers (often, tearing them to shreds) and doing their best to include all factors that could effect existing figures and consensus undesrstanding. This is the scientific process! If you cant criticise your peers, or you cant accept valid scientifically sound criticisms yourself, you are not only a bad scientist but your career will actually be stilted by it because of the way that surviving criticism / peer-rewiew is actually CRUCIAL to earning respect in the science community.

-The difference here (and the reason that critical analysis of existing research and assumptions is usually NOT shunned) is when sceptical scientists claim that their findings counter completely the established scientific consensus. Again, no scientist's career can survive ignoring soundly-made (and peer-critiqued without major flaws being exposed) research that disproves or casts into doubt his own conclusions, without taking these on board.

Part of the trouble is that 100% perfect methodically-impeccable research is as rare as unicorns, and the authors of flawed data are often reluctant to own the fact wholly; but this is why the whole world of science is founded upon consensus that is formed by debate and critical peer review, so that bias is countered by the aggregate (and meta-analysis) of all the good and best-quality research out there.

Less commonly, people are also shunned when the science is actually undertaken dishonestly and in bad faith, much like the 'experts' who were paid to deny the impacts of petrolleum lead-pollution in the air for years, or that a cigerette a day was good for you!

Exxon knew in 1968 -its on google. Stanford Reseach Institute (SRI) scientists Elmer Robinson and R.C. Robbins produced a Final Report to the American Petroleum Institute (API) on SRI’s research in the sources, abundance, and fate of gaseous pollutants in the atmosphere. They reserved their starkest warnings to industry leaders for carbon dioxide. Robinson observed that, among the pollutants reviewed, carbon dioxide "is the only air pollutant which has been proven to be global importance to man's environment on the basis of a long period of scientific investigation." Summarizing the findings of the President’s Science Advisory Council, Robinson noted that CO2 emissions from fossil fuels were outstripping the natural CO2 removal processes that keep the atmosphere in equilibrium. He noted that the speed of CO2 accumulation would depend on fossil fuel consumption and projected that, on then-present trends, atmospheric CO2 could reach 400ppm by 2000, and that exploiting all then-recoverable fossil fuel would lead to concentrations of 830ppm. The report warned that rising CO2 would result in increases in temperature at the earth's surface, and that significant temperature increase could lead to melting ice caps, rising seas, and potentially serious environmental damage worldwide. It noted that, even if Antarctic ice caps took 1000 years to melt, this would mean sea level rises of four feet per ten years—"100 times greater than observed changes." Importantly, SRI acknowledged that of the various sources proposed for rising atmospheric CO2, "none seems to fit the presently observed situation as well as the fossil fuel emanation theory." Noting uncertainties about whether particulate pollution would offset some of this warming, SRI warned "…there seems to be no doubt that the potential damage to our environment could be severe…" The industry's own consulting scientists then confirmed that the most urgent research need was into technologies that could bring CO2 emissions under control.

He knows far more about climate change than Obama, Gore and for sure Bernie Sanders and Hillary. And Leonardo DeCRAPO or Neil deGrasse Tyson


S. FRED SINGER

The single most important issue is whether climate change is natural or human-caused. In principle, both options are plausible. But we know climate changes naturally, on times scales of decades and centuries.

So which is more important: the human release of gases or natural cycles? One cannot go by the majority view--science does not work like politics.

We cannot use the fact that there is a rough correlation between temperature increase and increase in CO2. During much of the 20th century, from 1940 to 1975, the climate cooled while CO2 levels rose. And during the past decade climate has again been cooling in spite of the rise in CO2.

The answer is to look at the pattern of warming trends and see if it agrees with what models predict. The models all predict the existence of a "hot spot" -- a maximum warming trend in the tropical region. The observations from weather balloons show the opposite result, a slight cooling trend. This disagreement between calculated and observed fingerprints of temperature trends is the strongest argument against any appreciable human contribution to climate.

THE FOLLOWING IS PART OF THE SAME ARTICLE:

It might make a lot more sense to draw a correlation between man-made carbon dioxide levels and the rising temperatures if the temperatures hadn't decreased in the last decade.

"The Earth's climate has always alternated between warming and cooling phases," said William Happer, who served the Department of Energy under former President George H. W. Bush. "In the medieval warming period, when the Norse settled Greenland, the Earth warmed as fast or faster that it has since the 1800's. What should world governments have done in the year 900 A.D., when people noticed that the climate was warming and the ice was melting in southern Greenland?"

Studies show that average global temperatures have decreased as much as 0.2 degrees Celsius over the last ten years----just as human activity is thought to be taking its biggest toll on the planet's climate.

The decrease is small, to be sure, but, say skeptics, it disproves the argument that rising man-made CO2 levels are the driving force behind global warming.

10 factors to consider when comparing atmospheric carbon levels between Venus and Earth

1. Venus has no plant life
2. Plant life absorbs radiation
3. Evaporation causes a cooling affect
4. Plant life increases the precipitation and evaporation cycle ie Amazon Jungle
5. Cloud cover reflects heat
6. The Amazon also raises the cloud altitude level thus cooling the H2O
7. Plant life transfer's heat to the ground via the root system
8. Carbon increases significantly the plant growth thus adding to these cooling methods
9. The carbon cycle balances between parts per million(PPM)and plant growth
10. Carbon PPM plateau level simply increases in proportion to the global output rate, a lag in the carbon cycle ie, If carbon output suddenly stopped tomorrow, the PPM would start lowering until the plants started suffocating.

Any figure like the immutable 97% consensus raises immediate suspicion in intelligent minds. There are a few things that just pop up. In a highly controversial field such as Climatology, it would be nearly impossible to get 97% agreement on ANYTHING. "97%" is the kind of figure that one expects from an election in Saddam Hussein's Iraq or Asad's Syria. Equally troubling, the figure stays the same year after year. Looking at the results of ANY poll by a reputable research organization such as Pew or Gallup, one NEVER finds static data. Everything differs from week to week, and also from poll to poll. The day that any poll result remains constant in time and among sources, is the day that one can be sure that the polls are phony.

Sonicisbadazz - you should remain skeptical and “open-minded”, because you haven’t studied this matter for 20 years, as I have. I provided a very rational approach to the question of whether or not CO2 drives climate. However, empiricists are equally satisfied by satellite measurements which have failed to show the warming predicted by global climate models. You likely think some 97% of scientists believe atmospheric CO2 drives global climate. That’s false. Look up the records of those surveys, and you’ll learn what they really measured. In any case, I posted with certainty because there’s no doubt in my mind about the science here. But you don’t have to accept it yourself. Indeed, you should study this for yourself (if you can). The atmosphere does not have a measurable mass, so it is equally impossible to know the CO2 mass is 3280 Gt. However, this statistic has never been refuted. It comes from assuming the 410 ppmv statistic is correct (Scripps Observatory observational record), and the statistic 5.15E+18 kg is a close estimate of the earth’s atmospheric mass. Since air has an average mass of 28.97 g/mol, and CO2 is 44.01 g/mol, one must convert from volume to mass using a factor 44.01/28.97 = 1.52. Therefore, 410 ppmv becomes 622.85 ppmg. Multiply by 5.15E+18 to get 3207.70 Gt. The math is greatly simplified by increasing CO2 level to 3280 Gt, which enables an “easy” calculation 3280 Gt / 410 ppmv = 8 Gt / ppmv. The closer approximation is 7.82 Gt / ppmv. Back in 1955, when the CO2 level was 315 ppmv, one may derive total atmospheric CO2 = 2464 Gt. This yields an average annual CO2 increase = 3207.7 - 2464.5 = 743.25 / 65 years = 11.43 Gt / year. I rounded this up to 16 Gt with simplified math. So, 11.43 / 7.82 = +1.46 ppmv. Of course, the actual record is nonlinear, but this only makes the lack of correlation between CO2 and global warming even less likely. Higher temperatures in the 1930s were “adjusted” out of existence in the “official” HadCRUT record (Hadley Centre, U. of East Anglia, Norwich, England). The last 22 years have lacked any observational warming, except in records boosted by global climate model projected temperatures. Satellites failed to show warming during the 20 years when they should have shown more than the late 20th century.

The problem as I see it is this: We don't know exactly where we stand with relation to the argument. The science, while I wouldn't classify it as 'all over the place', differs enough that we cannot pinpoint where we stand. That means there is a substantial (not overwhelming) margin of error in whatever data you are analyzing. As you look into the future, the margin of error necessarily increases. Therefore trying to analyze 10 or 20-years down the road the actions taken today is virtually impossible. IMO, smart money says we invest in appropriate research. Research funded without the possibility of a never-ending stream of money. The research cannot be tied to future revenues in order to take away that incentive. How you remove the politics from the science is equally difficult and I would have to look to someone smarter than me to find a resolution. But once we are confident in the science, we should be able to make reasonable decisions based on that science and not on politics, fear mongering, or making billionaires out of non-deserving benefactors. Meanwhile, it makes perfectly good sense to pursue reasonable ways to reduce pollution and increase carbon retention.

Even the stupidest person should realize that a 1 or 2 degree increase in the global climate poses no threat to anyone on planet earth. Almost all life on the planet has adapted to survive in a wide range of temperatures. Even a 4-5 degree increase isn't dangerous. Most life is adapted to survive swings as great as 50 - 150 degrees as we go through the seasons from summer to winter.

The real fear is that global warming will raise sea levels. But here are the facts. The arctic ice is sea ice. It already displaces the ocean as much as it ever will. Even if the entire arctic were to melt the sea level wouldn't rise even 1 millimeter. In order to raise sea levels by any appreciable degree the Antarctic ice would have to melt.

The first question to ask is what is the melting point of ice? Everyone knows it's 32 degrees F.

The next question is what is the average temperature of Antarctica? -56 degrees F.

Well what is the average summer temperature of Antarctica? -10 degrees F.

Unless the laws of physics change and ice starts melting at much lower temperatures it's impossible for the Antarctic ice to melt and impossible for the global sea level to rise by any appreciable extent.

Not surprisingly even during periods in earths history that were much much warmer than today the Antarctic ice didn't melt.

So if there is no chance we are about to be inundated by rising ocean levels, then what are people so worried about?

You would think the alarmists would at least take the time to double check the melting point of ice against the temperature in Antarctica before making absurd predictions that have no chance of ever coming true.

There's no science of "climatology" that makes you simultaneously an expert in all the technical fields related to climate in ways that mere physicists and biologists and geologists are not. But at some point we all have to get out of our silos to get an overview of the issue. As people often point out as though it were a badge of shame, I'm a historian. The modern solar panel degrades in output by about 1% per year. Things made out of silicon, manufactured into electronics like flat-screen TVs, get cheaper over time as they refine the process. Power plants have to purchase coal or gas to burn so that steam can be generated to drive a turbine that produces electricity. It's agreed that CO2 is a greenhouse gas, but what they don't say is how much humans dump into the atmosphere, probably because it is a staggering amount. Globally, we generate over 10 billion tons of CO2 annually, and we know it has a warming effect. We know that over the last 800,000 years, CO2 levels have varied from 180 to about 280 ppm during natural climate cycles, and that today it is at 425 ppm. We've risen 1 degree Celsius in about a century, and during normal climate cycles that change takes about 7,000 years. We know what causes natural climate change and that the planet should be entering a slow cooling period, yet it is warming; something is overriding the natural climate cycle; this is not natural variation. We know it is not changes in solar energy output. If you want to say it isn't human activity, then you need to offer an alternate hypothesis, but you can't, because all other possible causes have been ruled out. Weather is not the same thing as climate, and climatology is a science; there are climatologists. Survey climatologists instead of meteorologists, and let us know if you find consensus. How many countries are members of the Paris Accord? All of them (197). How many intend to back out? One. The new head of the EU intends to accelerate emission cutting, and China is ahead of their pledge. She talked about sanctions and trade barriers for countries not pulling their weight. That could get interesting. If we reverse fuel standards, our cars will no longer sell overseas; coal mining continues to fall despite deregulation, because of market forces. There are 10 times more jobs in clean energy than there are in coal. Apple now produces 80% of its corporate power needs. There are zealots who predicted radical change over short periods of time a few decades ago, especially about sea levels, but the predictions from the actual scientific community have been quite accurate, and the models continue to improve. Maybe you're not sure the science is right, but are you sure it is wrong?!

An update on current thinking and the science of climate change.

Everyone has been fooled and both the American and British media have openly been told not to interview anyone who disputes that it is humans that have caused the climate to change. If the oil and gas had not been used, where would all the plastics have come from (which sadly, humans dump in landfill sites, rivers, and the sea!)?
