(See a partial list of 6,000 products made from oil at https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/partial-list-over-6000-products-made-from-one-barrel-oil-steve-pryor ).  How would we have produced the energy we have used? How would we have transported food and goods around the planet...by horse and cart and rowing boats? How would we have heated and cooled our homes? Well, we could have cut down ALL of the trees I suppose...It is bad enough that we have cut down most of the trees in most countries and in particular around the tropics where the tree cover historically controlled the world climate! Those living in or near or visiting the rainforest will be aware of how tropical rains are absorbed by the trees very quickly after a storm since each tree can absorb its own weight in water. Evaporation in the rainforest helps to keep the temperature down, particularly in the tropics, whereas cleared land retains the radiant heat of the sun. Then look at the main real current proximate cause of climate change... THE POLE SHIFT!  A great resume of the global warming scam can be seen at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vyig6r8lgWE&t=14s ;
Of greater effect on the world, the extreme climate change is hastened by the destruction of the forest, particularly around the tropics where lack of trees to absorb the sun's radiation causes tropical (not global) warming and the absorption of much more moisture from the tropical seas as a result of higher air and sea temperature. Global solar minimum records may have been a guide to future climate from past records, however, the effects of the pole shift are altering global conditions and projections from historic records and cycles. At the last GSM, we were not experiencing the extreme temperatures and extreme weather events now being recorded! Also, we did not experience such a huge increase in earthquakes and volcanic activity. (Sometimes as many as 4000 earthquakes over 2.5 on the Richter scale each month instead of 200, 16 years ago and over 70 erupting volcanoes each month as opposed to 3, 16 years ago.) Huge cracks and sink-holes have also increased year by year in the last 16 years as a result of the stress on the crust from the current crustal slip. 

So one cause for the escalation of extreme weather events is simple... fewer trees in the tropics each year....less to absorb the sun's radiation = tropical warming (NOT GLOBAL WARMING!). Higher temperature around the tropics = more moisture evaporated from the oceans producing much warmer, denser and increased cloud production (hence more flooding in tropics where tree cover is reduced).....then more and denser ‘tropical rainforest clouds’ carrying more moisture, escape the tropics as intense heat on cleared land creates lift to allow these clouds to escape the tropics on trade winds...hence regional cooling effect away from the tropics as cloud cover increases and increased rain and snowfall away from the tropics, whilst extra cloud cover also traps the extra heat traveling up from the tropics. Fewer trees in the tropics each year = less biomass to sequester the CO2.  As the ocean warms, the warmer seas travel north to the Arctic and south to the Antarctic. As warmer air from the tropics travels north and south, the air is warmer in the Arctic and in the Antarctic....simples!’ The warmer air and seas distorts the position of the jet stream pushing it north towards west Canada and north towards the UK but there is a counteractive force pushing the jet stream south at some geographical locations as a result of the increase in cloud cover escaping the Tropics, which cools some areas of the ocean through reduced radiation from the sun.  Nature operates its own controls. Cut down and burn the trees and the increase in CO2 inspire nature to inspire more growth to absorb and balance the CO2 bank.

So what is happening at the geographic poles? Arctic melting = more cold water escaping the north. Pole shift causing the magnetic north pole to move towards Siberia = the cold waters of the Kara and East Siberian sea also moving into the Atlantic. As Siberia moves up to the new geographical northern point, the colder air of northern Siberia is also moving towards the Atlantic, USA and Europe with the jet stream. (Low temperatures are retained better by landmasses!) As North America moves south, the Jet stream is distorted by the cold water and air from the melting Arctic, the cold water from the Kara and East Siberian Sea as well as the northern tip of Siberia which has had -83 degrees recorded in winter 2017-18 and domestic and wild animals freezing to death, just as the many animals that froze to death in previous cold periods.  

Much of the hysteria about seasonal climate change forget that climate is driven by the seasons and the geographical position of the sun throughout the year. Cloud generation and therefore flooding accelerates when the sun crosses the equator and cloud generation increases as it follows the sun, providing localized seasonal changes in rainfall on changing seasonal regional land surfaces. It is often said by some that cosmic radiation causes cloud nucleation, however, the moisture/humidity has to exist if indeed new cloud is formed by this method. World weather maps generated from satellite data, confirm that the amount of cloud generated around the tropics has increased exponentially, with the loss of forest and as a result of landmass displacement following of the current crustal displacement caused by the current pole shift.

Currently, the immense mass of the core continues to spin in its historic attitude. The crust is slipping...north America southwards and Australia northwards. Hence Mexico, California and southern US states, as well as Australia, are moving towards the equator where droughts and forest fires are increasing year by year. Florida and the Florida keys are seeing seawater ingress up the drains at high tide and Louisiana backwaters are now full of saltwater as these areas approach the bulge of the ocean at the tropics distorted by the oscillation of the moon and sun north and south of the equator. The Louisiana freshwater shrimp fisheries have collapsed as a result. This localized sea-level rise has been increasing during the past 16 years as a result of the pole shift. With the forest areas of Amazon, Philippines and Indonesia moving away from the tropics, falling tree cover has increased tropical temperature (not global warming) and increased moisture absorption from tropical seas. Hence more and denser cloud generation around the tropics providing additional moisture for the flooding and snowfall on the increase over the past 16 years, north and south of the equator. Sadly this has also contributed to regional colder air north and south of the equator since the increased cloud cover has prevented warmth reaching the Earth's surface.

"Man Made Global Warming"? Natural fires of grasslands, and forests, have been a part of the ecosystem for eons. Volcanos also spew out heat, and toxic gasses of every kind. As we all know, the Earth's Crust floats upon a mass of molten rock.  Every coal miner knows how hot it gets just a few dozen meters below surface. We also witness intense heat radiating from calderas, such as those found in Yellowstone, or as in Iceland, and many other locations. Of all the Greenhouse gasses in our atmosphere, Water Vapor is the most common, and plays a much greater role in climate. CO2 is not a "Blanket Gas", and has always been a trace-gas in proportion to other Greenhouse gasses; such as Methane, which is more common than CO2. So, please do not be fooled by the Climate Change Wackos! Let the facts as proven by patient, sober, and capable scientific methods, such as satellite data collected over the last 20 years, be a better guide in determining the facts. Neither "Global Warming", nor "Sea Rise" claims have physical evidence to back them.

The/that data tells. Not tell. Even if the other is dictionary acceptable, it's still nails on a chalk board. Some data, or a lot of data, it's a term for a collection of numbers and other facts, which can then be processed into information. So it doesn't matter if it's 5 'points' or 50, or 50 whole studies. it's all still just the data. (it's still one pile., even though the pile in one case may be bigger than in another).

Yeah, no. So few people use that plural form that it is just plain fecked up. Data is like an elemental metal or gas. It can be split into discrete units - bars of metal, volumes of gas, or points of data, but when combined, they are referred to as either, multiple units, or, the other term singularly. Example, a pallet of gold bars is either, a pallet of gold bars, or, a lot of gold, in which case, the article is the, not those. Data is the same thing. Many data points make data the same as a few. And in the end the aggregate is singular. Again, you can point to the dictionary all you want. I'm telling you that is wrong.

We very much appreciate precision in language as in other areas. But data is both the plural of datum (Latin for something given) and also frequently a collective noun. So sometimes the data tells us things, and sometimes the data tell us things.

The basis for this video seems to be a (warranted) gripe about CNN's sensationalist claim that 97% of climate experts think climate change is real and man-made. I agree - CNN (a news outlet, not a scientific body) was wrong. But I also disagree: a majority (depending on the data the video provides itself, varying from 52% - 82%) of climate experts still share a consensus view that a) climate change is real and b) human activity plays a significant role.

As for whether climate change is a dangerous threat or not, I invite you to read about the 'runaway greenhouse effect'. It's basically a positive feedback loop where warming leads to more warming which leads to more warming ... which leads to an uninhabitable planet. This is obviously a worst case scenario and thus very unlikely, but answers the question that yes, climate change can be dangerous (not taking into account the more realistic consequences such as increased power and frequency of tropical storms, flooding, droughts etc). As such it should be taken seriously and should be considered in policy decisions.


Watching this video has made me realise that yes, it is at least possible that I've been hoodwinked by a mass media conspiracy promoting a fear of climate change to push for greener technologies. But even if that is the case (which I don't think it is) I think it's better than the alternative (which is that climate change is real and we do nothing to prevent it). Let's look at some potential scenarios, A and B. Scenario A: climate change is real. Scenario B: climate change is not real.


Scenario A
1. We prepare: the effects of climate change are mitigated.
2. We don't prepare: global temperatures soar, resulting with its associated dangers (floods, crop failure, drought, famine, mass migrations, loss of coastal areas ... potential runaway greenhouse effect).


Scenario B
1. We prepare: economies invest heavily into green technologies 'for no reason' (still benefit from cleaner air and less environmental damage from mining etc)
2. We don't prepare: life continues as always.


In both scenarios, option 1 is better. Feel free to reply with your own version(s) of scenarios A/B option 1/2 if you think I'm being unfair with my assumptions here. Anyway, thank you for the video and the food for thought, it's been fun to question my own thoughts about this topic.

I simply can't understand people who think looking at 100 years makes any sense. Really you need to look at geological time so you get a better understanding. For example: we are currently in an ice age. Yes, that's right an ice age. Within ice ages you get periods of warming and periods of cooling referred to as interglacial and glacial periods. We are in an interglacial (ie warming period). These periods are caused by the tilt of the earth, wobbling around the earth's axis and also by movement of the tectonic plates. After the interglacial period we are in comes to an end we will enter a cooling period when it might be a bit handy to have some extra CO2 around so we don't all freeze to death. So actually stuff is really hard to measure and it's really complicated.

Models of course include clouds, the sun TSI (including the 11 year cycle), water vapour, and a host of other factors I'm certain you've never heard of before, such as changing albedo. Even the earlier models from the 1980s have proven themselves as surprisingly accurate, however they have tended to be a bit too conservative and have either underestimated the reaction to forcings and feedbacks, or whose highest error bars have coincided with the lowest error bars in actual observation. Of course water vapour is the biggest greenhouse gas, and that's what makes it a concern because it's concentration on average is dictated by air temperature. Scientists expect the feedback forcing of water vapour to increase by 7% for every 1 degree C rise in temperature from CO2 forcing. That's more than just significant, and explains why we're already 1 degree higher today than before the industrial age even though CO2 concentrations are not yet doubled. For your sun issue, here is a recent NASA graph showing the trend of the suns energy reaching earth to the average global temperatures for the last several decades: https://climate.nasa.gov/climate_resources/189/graphic-temperature-vs-solar-activity/ Scientists know about the heat island effect (not just the alt-right bloggers). The methodology used to adjust and/or exclude such data is well documented and not under dispute in the scientific community. Your children should be very angry and scared. There have been110 climate change models published since 1997, many funded by the IPCC. And every single one has failed to correctly predict anything. It is a basic tenant of science, that if a theory is not able to accurately predict an outcome or cannot be verified through testing/observation then it is false. The “models” that assume that CO2 level is a GW prime forcer; driving global temperature are the ones which are the most inaccurate. Most of the "models" assume temperature sensitivity to CO2 which is ridiculously high and this is not supported by science at all. It's been PROVEN that CO2 levels only rise after temperatures has already risen with a lag time of 800 years. CO2 has been put foremost as the global warming driver for political reasons, and until the fraudsters get rid of this "the science is settled" attitude (in an attempt to shut down further discussion), they will continue to be proven wrong. The severe credibility erosion, to the powers that be, of the “models” being consistently proven wrong, has led to several fraudulent acts.. Firstly, bodies such as NASA, NOAA and East Anglia University (to name just three) have actually falsified climate data. The latter has had emails leaked documenting complicity with the IPCC showing clear intention to falsify data reporting. Secondly, they kick the can down the road with erroneous predictions which had become due in say 2010 just get extended to say 2025. Thirdly, when they have insufficient data points, NASA and NOAA in particular, just plug in extrapolated climate data from the very “model” they are using. Fourthly, they truncate the historical data to exclude periods of greater warmth than today, to make it look like a warming spike and not part of a cooling-warming-cooling-warming natural cycle. This is what generated the infamous (and totally discredited) Mann “Hockey Stick”. Many “models” have excluded the Medieval Warm Period (300 years long) but include temperature data from the Mini Ice Age using “data smoothing” to not draw attention to the fact that as recently as 1250 AD, the medieval pre-industrial world was much warmer than it is now. Dr. Tim Ball made the same points and was sued for defamation in a SLAPP suit filed by the then-editor of the Journal of Climate, Andrew Weaver. Ball had been a professor of geography at the University of Winnipeg and knew a thing or two about historical climate change, including the medieval warm period and the so-called 'climate optimum.' He could see Weaver, a computer modeller, knew very little about historical climatology and mentioned it in an online article he wrote. Weaver said Ball defamed him, but really Weaver's suit was designed to shut Ball up and keep him out of the climate debate (SLAPP = Strategic Lawsuit Against Public Participation). Shortly after filing his SLAPP suit, Weaver became the leader of the British Columbia Green Party and enjoyed a pivotal role in BC politics. In contrast, Tim Ball was vilified as a 'climate change denier', a pejorative term akin to 'Holocaust denier'. The story has a happy ending though: after a long legal battle, a judge dismissed Weaver's suit. There's a lot about it online, including this: https://wattsupwiththat.com/2018/02/13/breaking-tim-balls-free-speech-victory-over-andrew-weaver-all-charges-dismissed/

What is the point of debunking one false claim only to make another?
CO2 is not a "greenhouse gas". The so called "greenhouse effect" is an hypothesis.
The IPCC claim that CO2 is a so called "Greenhouse Gas" because it has strong IR absorption and emission bands at 15µm.
According to Wien's displacement law, 15µm radiation has a corresponding temperature of minus -80º C.
The troposphere, (that's the bit of the atmosphere we live in) is defined by molecules which have a temperature of minus -60º C and above.
IR emissions from CO2 @ 15µm cannot heat any molecules in the troposphere, it would be a violation of the laws of thermodynamics and is impossible. 
Outside of the 15µm absorption and emission bands, CO2 is indistinguishable from the rest of the molecules in the air, in accordance with the ideal gas law.
When they say that the "greenhouse effect is settled science", the truth is 180º the opposite.
The so called "greenhouse effect" is an hypothesis i.e. pure conjecture. Nothing could be further from being settled science.
The "greenhouse effect" hypothesis is and always has been, as I have stated above, a contravention of the laws of physics and therefore completely at odds with the "settled science".

You’ve bought into the false narrative that CO2 is a magic thermostatic control of the climate, which is absolute bunk. The ‘greenhouse’ atmospheric gas that has the huge lion’s share of effect on our climate is water vapor - roughly 90% of the effect. Of the remaining 10%, CO2 drives about 30% of the effect, or 3% overall. CO2 does not have the thermodynamic influence to do as the alarmists claim. In fact, CO2 is essential to life as we know it, and if levels get too low (<180PPM) plant life is compromised, ending our existence. Human activity has helped to drive CO2 levels to approx 387PPM currently, which has resulted in a greening of the earth (20%, as observed by satellites). As the earth greens, guess what? The increased plant life stores the CO2, rinse and repeat. This nonsense that CO2 is a poison to lives or the climate would be humorous if it weren’t for the tax and societal polices that many are encouraging to radically restructure our lives. @Steve Warren Oh, you didn't even understand what I said. You don 't even know what science is since you identify it with a religion. Science is about *precision.* In pure science, everything we say is true with respect to the axioms we chose (and because the language is precise, anybody can actually check this truth — that's mathematics). Applied science works with reality and models. We try to find models that fit what we observe, so that we can have a better understanding of relations between the phenomenons we're studying, and we can predict how things will work in other situations. And when a model doesn't fit reality anymore, we just ditch it. That's how we were able to build all the things that are around you! for example, satellites wouldn't exist at all without science. A real scientific study always includes all the details they used to gather data, to process that data, and to arrive to the conclusion they obtained, *in a very precise language that has no ambiguities whatsoever.* So a scientific article is just this. They say: we mesured this using this technique, we gathered that much data in that much time using this sampling method. Then we concluded this (and possibly we propose a new model that improves some other ones). Science is not a religion, it's about honesty. Saying what they did, how they did, and why they concluded what they concluded. The problem is when this precise information is diluted, simplified and distorted. That's why uneducated people can loose faith in science, but it's a ridiculous shortcut. Because they don't know what science is. And you trying to put science down using lies and historical rewriting is just going against using science properly! *We actually need more science.* That's the only way we can push these politics and other people trying to manipulate us into their own contradictions so that it's eventually clear that *they are lying to us.* It's with *science* that we can do that. @Bill Leach Well I'm sorry Bill but some things in science ARE obviously settled, like that the earth is indeed "round" (in a fashion) rather than flat. In that example there isn't any "outlier data" that isn't accounted for. There is all manner of science that we know works extremely reliably and predictably in the real world, and is therefore "settled". Of course one can always delve into finer, lower level detail and find new questions to ask - this process is probably infinite, but the high level stuff that matters to the layman (like are we likely f*cking up our climate or not?) can indeed be "settled". What I object to is the use of this argument ("there's no such thing as settled science) as a catch-all / cop-out specious argument, to dispute what really are well established scientific "facts".

@Russell Chandler No, what a stupid thing to say! Science is never settled precisely because it is ALWAYS subject to revision based upon new observation or even new understanding of previous observations. There is, for example, no such thing as "outlier data" in real science. What the "world" does is fact, science is there to try to understand what we observe. If an "outlier" is not due to error in method, data collection, or data analysis, then scientific theory is incomplete until it can explain why the outlier exists... and not just with a "Oh that happens sometimes" sort of explanation such as you see so often in the behavioral sciences. So called science that can not produce generative models that accurately and reliably produce predictions with correlation factors of 0.95 or greater are not science at all but only opinion. Most of what you see as "Climate Science" (at least that reported on by the media) is of this latter form (i.e. not science at all).

''The Medieval Warm Period also known as the Medieval Climate Optimum, or Medieval Climatic Anomaly was a time of warm climate in the North Atlantic region lasting from c. 950 to c. 1250. It was likely related to warming elsewhere while some other regions were colder, such as the tropical Pacific. Average global mean temperatures have been calculated to be similar to early-mid-20th-century warming. Possible causes of the Medieval Warm Period include increased solar activity, decreased volcanic activity, and changes to ocean circulation. The period was followed by a cooler period in the North Atlantic and elsewhere termed the Little Ice Age. Some refer to the event as the Medieval Climatic Anomaly as this term emphasizes that climatic effects other than temperature were important. It is thought that between c. 950 and c. 1100 was the Northern Hemisphere's warmest period since the Roman Warm Period.'' - Wikipedia

BRAVO! This was a great debunk of the 97% myth. Worth doing the easy math again on the Cook study:
* 66% took no position.
* Of the 34% that took a position, Cook authors claimed 97% endorsed AGW.
* The Cook study admits it counted papers that took no position as "implicitly endorsing" AGW (Table 3 and Page 6).
* The Cook study admitted that 75% of the 97% were "implicit endorsement" (Table 3 and Page 6).
* The REAL figure is 8% of the papers endorsed AGW.
* Worth nothing that they tabulated mostly papers, not studies. Papers are not rigorous studies and represent an opinion not the scientific method nor "science fact" nor "settled science".
I encourage people to read the Cook study themselves (it's 8 pages long). Pay attention to Tables 2 & 3 and Page 6 and do the math for yourselves!

The science on manmade climate change is FAR from settled! There is NO concensus of 97% of climate scientists. (That was based on flawed data but you can look that up for yourself) This is what some of the scientists who have worked at the IPCC ,past and present. had to say. See the noteworthy links provided by the Australian scientist. UN Scientists Who Have Turned on the UN IPCC & Man-Made Climate Fears — A Climate Depot Flashback Report https://www.climatedepot.com/2013/08/21/un-scientists-who-have-turned-on-unipcc-man-made-climate-fears-a-climate-depot-flashback-report/ Updated – Climate Scientists Write To UN: There Is No Climate Emergency https://www.technocracy.news/climate-scientists-write-to-un-there-is-no-climate-emergency/ From 2014 The IPCC's Latest Report Deliberately Excludes And Misrepresents Important Climate Science https://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2014/03/31/the-ipccs-latest-report-deliberately-excludes-and-misrepresents-important-climate-science/#32ff4141428e As for being skeptical about the IPCC's climate change predictions: We must first remember that the IPCC is part of the UN System. It is a POLITICAL body. It is NOT a scientific body. How have past dire predictions of climate alarmists fared? Climate Alarmists Have Been Wrong About Virtually Everything https://www.thenewamerican.com/tech/environment/item/22289-climate-alarmists-have-been-wrong-about-virtually-everything Climate Alarm: Failed Prognostications https://www.instituteforenergyresearch.org/climate-change/climate-alarm-failed-prognostications/ But the best reason for being skeptical about the IPCC climate change predictions is simply to consider the source of the predictions: Computer Models of the climate Computer models are only as good as the program that is written for them, what data is nput and how well these reflect the real world reality. Predictions resulting from computer modeling can not be considered to be scientific fact. The more accurately the model reflects reality, the higher the probability that the prediction will come to pass. Useful Computer Modeling of the entire climate of earth is still in its infancy. It uses only a few variables that cannot possibly include or accurately reflect all that goes into making up our climate which itself is fluid and ever -changing. Climate is the result of complex sets of interactions of physical systems , each with their own sets of variables that can range from a few in number to thousands to millions depending on how far you want to break them down. Breaking them down is limited only by the level of our knowledge, which is presently at the quantum level of interactions. The systems forming our climate are not limited to earth systems but range through space to the sun. Science does yet fully understand the formation of our climate. Suffice it to say that our computer modeling is as of yet , far too simplistic to accurately reflect our climate making most of the meaningful or accurate predictions for such a complex set of interactions nearly impossible

If we search the literature on paleoclimatology we find the answers we are looking for. There has been very clear weather behavior for over 400,000 years showing a natural climate fluctuation. Climate depends on solar activity, planetary motion and the precession of the earth's axis of rotation, as well as underwater volcanic activity, among other things. The human being has very little to do with it all

There has been very clear weather behavior for over 400,000 years showing a natural climate fluctuation -- Yes. But never has it changed at such a fast rate as it has now. Hence the classic "hockey stick" graph shape that has been recreated with different data again again. That is where the concern lies. Our temperature shouldn't have 50,000 years worth of normal fluctuation happen in 50 years. "Climate depends on solar activity" -- This was actually a huge hypothesis in the inception of this climate problem in the late 20th century. And even recent studies show that solar output has increased within this last century. But the sun's output also stopped increasing late in the century and the heating trend still continues. It's possible the increase helped raise temperatures, but it did not account for the entirety of the raise, especially in the later portion of time where the sun did not continue to heat up yet earths temperature still did. ", planetary motion" -- This doesn't really affect the climate. Not sure how it could given that our orbit is nearly perfectly circular and the periapsis and apoapsis of our orbit are reached multiple times per year so any difference between them would not accumulate. " and the precession of the earth's axis of rotation" -- That's how seasons happen. The rate of our procession is not changing. How would this warm the earth on a global scale? " as well as underwater volcanic activity, among other things. " Volcanic activity only amounts for up to half a gigaton of co2 a year for particularly active years (down to .12GT for less). Human cars alone emit more than 3 gigatons/yr. Volcanoes do contribute a lot, but historically without humans, this gets balanced out by other factors like ocean absorption (and subsequent conversion to seashells in cooler waters). It's the human element that introduces a disruption to the natural slow ebb and flow of this greenhouse accumulation and that's what tips the scales into warming trend.

People do realise that they are criticising the numbers provided in the various surveys and papers for being misleading, and then intentionally do exactly the same thing right?

The surveys they refer to all, separately from different sources and methodologies, established around a 97% consensus. And the consensus is that anthropogenic climate change is real. No strawman arguments about risk needed.

https://skepticalscience.com/97-percent-consensus-robust.htm

https://skepticalscience.com/global-warming-scientific-consensus-intermediate.htm

https://skepticalscience.com/Consensus-Project-self-rating-data-now-available.html

"Nevertheless, the existence of the expert consensus on human-caused global warming is a reality, as is clear from an examination of the full body of evidence. For example, Naomi Oreskes found no rejections of the consensus in a survey of 928 abstracts performed in 2004. Doran & Zimmerman (2009) found a 97% consensus among scientists actively publishing climate research. Anderegg et al. (2010) reviewed publicly signed declarations supporting or rejecting human-caused global warming, and again found over 97% consensus among climate experts. Cook et al. (2013) found the same 97% result through a survey of over 12,000 climate abstracts from peer-reviewed journals, as well as from over 2,000 scientist author self-ratings, among abstracts and papers taking a position on the causes of global warming."

"Critics of our paper have pointed to a blog post that asked 7 scientists to rate their own papers. We'd already done that, except rather than cherry pick a handful of scientists known to hold contrarian views, we blanket emailed over 8,500 scientists. This resulted in 1,200 scientists rating the level of endorsement of their own climate papers, with 2,142 papers receiving a self-rating.

While our analysis of abstracts found 97.1% consensus among abstracts stating a position on anthropogenic global warming (AGW), the method of self-rating complete papers independently found 97.2% consensus among papers self-rated as stating a position on AGW. This independent confirmation demonstrates how robust the scientific consensus is. Whether it's Naomi Oreskes' original analysis of climate research in 2004, Doran and Kendall-Zimmerman (2009) surveying the community of Earth scientists, Anderegg et al. (2010) analysing public declarations on climate change, or our own independent methods, the overwhelming consensus consistently appears."

https://www.iflscience.com/environment/atmosphere-scientist-slams-climate-change-deniers-in-brilliant-viral-post/

https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2015/aug/25/heres-what-happens-when-you-try-to-replicate-climate-contrarian-papers?fbclid=IwAR2ffeNNPuooiab-MhFy0EfvwYiZb6MRKbOMcV20s1xytqyK29RAuHL-h5o

When the papers in the 3% of papers denying AGW were looked at and their findings attempted to be replicated:

"Cherry picking was the most common characteristic they shared. We found that many contrarian research papers omitted important contextual information or ignored key data that did not fit the research conclusions."

"When we tried to reproduce their model of the lunar and solar influence on the climate, we found that the model only simulated their temperature data reasonably accurately for the 4,000-year period they considered. However, for the 6,000 years’ worth of earlier data they threw out, their model couldn’t reproduce the temperature changes. The authors argued that their model could be used to forecast future climate changes, but there’s no reason to trust a model forecast if it can’t accurately reproduce the past."

"You may have noticed another characteristic of contrarian climate research – there is no cohesive, consistent alternative theory to human-caused global warming. Some blame global warming on the sun, others on orbital cycles of other planets, others on ocean cycles, and so on. There is a 97% expert consensus on a cohesive theory that’s overwhelmingly supported by the scientific evidence, but the 2–3% of papers that reject that consensus are all over the map, even contradicting each other. The one thing they seem to have in common is methodological flaws like cherry picking, curve fitting, ignoring inconvenient data, and disregarding known physics."

@Politically Correct Redskin"Trace element": Here's why that's not a defense. As a photon of heat radiation travels outward, it encounters trillions of air molecules, so if 400/million are CO2, it will, on average, still encounter millions of CO2 molecules. BUT it only needs to hit 1 to be reflected back to earth. The green house effect would still happen with glass only a few microns thick. Volcanoes cool the atmosphere due to particulates that reflect sunlight (like dust particles; they have a greater effect than the CO2), since man puts out more than 10 billion tons of CO2 every year, no volcano even comes close. There are no 30 year cycles; the solar cycle 11 years, and all of the other natural climate cycles are thousands of years; 100,000 years for the ice age cycle. Those short-term warming/cooling events of the last few millennia were hemispheric, not global. There are 2,000 international climate scientists that work on the IPCC reports, and the U.S. is the only country in the world that will not be in the Paris Accord. @systematic101 That the world is greener is part of reaching the new equilibrium. It consumes CO2, but less than is added.

@systematic101 Unfortunately, there are feedback loops in other places: Adding greenhouse gas increases the temperature, which makes permafrost soil thaw. (The soil contains frozen organic substances.) That releases methane, which is a strong greenhouse gas. Adding it increases the temperature, and so on. And there is a lot of permafrost in Siberia.

@systematic101 The natural CO2 concentration is an equilibrium between CO2 emitted naturally and the CO2 consumed naturally. We add CO2. If we would add a little one time, that would cause a higher equilibrium, between the old value and the initial new value. It is lower than the initial new value because the consumed amount increases minimally too. If the consumed amount would decrease instead, it would be a feedback loop of increase of CO2 leading to more increase of CO2, leading to even more...

"Global emissions rose by 21% to 6.04 billion metric tons over the 12 years, mostly due to booming economic growth in India and China, where coal-fired energy output continues to expand. The truth, and it's proven by the hard data, is that CO2 made in the USA will not choke the world to death or cause it to massively overheat. And you can thank capitalism for that. Because capitalism, unlike socialism and its welfare-state kin, hates waste. So it does all it can to be efficient. That means using as little energy as possible to make things. And this predates any of the current CO2 hysteria. In the U.S., the data are clear and utterly convincing: In 1949, it took 1,098 metric tons of CO2 emissions to produce $1 million in GDP in the U.S., after adjusting for inflation. Today, it takes just 301 metric tons to produce that same million dollars, after inflation — a 73% gain in carbon-efficiency. Indeed, we're actually decarbonizing our economy, and rapidly. As new technologies continue to emerge, including better battery storage for alternative energy sources, safer nuclear power plants, and the fracking revolution that continues to make natural gas the energy of choice for conventional power plants, U.S. CO2 output is likely to continue to decline for every dollar of GDP produced. Instead of being harshly criticized by green groups and Euro-socialists, as has been the case for three decades now, we should be the model for green growth. When it comes to CO2, the U.S. is the leader. The rest of the world is the laggard. That's a fact".

There was a much larger, more comprehensive, and more recent survey carried out in 2016 titled “A 2016 National Survey of American Meteorological Society”. 4,092 AMS members participated. The finding are as follows:

“Nearly all AMS members (96%) think climate change is happening, with almost 9 out of 10 (89%) stating that they are either ‘extremely’ or ‘very’ sure it is happening. Only 1% think climate change is not happening, and 3% say they don’t know.”

“29% think the change is largely or entirely due to human activity (i.e., 81 to 100%); 38% think most of the change is caused by human activity (i.e., 61 to 80%); 14% think the change is caused more or less equally by human activity and natural events”

“7% think the change is caused mostly by natural events, 5% think the change is caused largely or entirely by natural events”

“6% say they don’t know, and 1% think climate change isn’t happening.”

We have the biased BBC and it`s dangerous agenda in the UK which shuts down anyone who wants to debate the subject of climate change. Copied from GWPF: The BBC program presented by Sir David Attenborough went far beyond its remit to present the facts of climate change, instead broadcasting a highly politicised manifesto in favour of renewable energy and unjustified alarm. The program highlighted suggestions that storms, floods, heatwaves and sea level rise are all rapidly getting worse as a result of climate change. However, the best available data, published in the last few years by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and NASA, contradicts the BBC’s alarmist exaggeration of empirical evidence. In its 5th Assessment Report (2013), the IPCC concluded: “Current datasets indicate no significant observed trends in global tropical cyclone frequency over the past century … No robust trends in annual numbers of tropical storms, hurricanes and major hurricanes counts have been identified over the past 100 years in the North Atlantic basin.” In its more recent Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5°C, published in 2018, these findings were reconfirmed. It stated that “Numerous studies towards and beyond AR5 have reported a decreasing trend in the global number of tropical cyclones and/or the globally accumulated cyclonic energy… There is consequently low confidence in the larger number of studies reporting increasing trends in the global number of very intense cyclones.” Regarding floods, the IPCC’s Special Report concluded: “There is low confidence due to limited evidence, however, that anthropogenic climate change has affected the frequency and the magnitude of floods. “ There is also no observational evidence that the rate of sea level rise is getting worse. NASA satellite data shows that since 1993, there has been an annual mean sea level rise of 3.3mm, with no significant level of acceleration in the last three decades. Suggestions by David Attenborough and Michael Mann that climate change is causing increases in wildfires in the US and globally are also misleading and not supported by any empirical evidence. According to a survey published by the Royal Society the global area burned has actually declined over past decades, and there is increasing evidence to suggest that there is less fire in the global landscape today than centuries ago. These are vitally important facts that should have been mentioned if an accurate description of the impact of climate change on wildfires was to be maintained. In his letter of complaint, Dr Benny Peiser, the GWPF’s director, has asked the BBC to acknowledge and correct the evident errors and misleading suggestions documented in the complaint and offer remedial measures as soon as possible.

Confirmation bias is the tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that affirms one's prior beliefs or hypotheses.[1] It is a type of cognitive bias and a systematic error of inductive reasoning. People display this bias when they gather or remember information selectively, or when they interpret it in a biased way. The effect is stronger for desired outcomes, for emotionally charged issues, and for deeply-entrenched beliefs.

People also tend to interpret ambiguous evidence as supporting their existing position. Biased search, interpretation and memory have been invoked to explain attitude polarization (when a disagreement becomes more extreme even though the different parties are exposed to the same evidence), belief perseverance (when beliefs persist after the evidence for them is shown to be false), the irrational primacy effect (a greater reliance on information encountered early in a series) and illusory correlation (when people falsely perceive an association between two events or situations).

A series of psychological experiments in the 1960s suggested that people are biased toward confirming their existing beliefs. Later work re-interpreted these results as a tendency to test ideas in a one-sided way, focusing on one possibility and ignoring alternatives. In certain situations, this tendency can bias people's conclusions. Explanations for the observed biases include wishful thinking and the limited human capacity to process information. Another explanation is that people show confirmation bias because they are weighing up the costs of being wrong, rather than investigating in a neutral, scientific way. However, even scientists and intelligent people can be prone to confirmation bias.


Confirmation biases contribute to overconfidence in personal beliefs and can maintain or strengthen beliefs in the face of contrary evidence. Poor decisions due to these biases have been found in political and organizational contexts.


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confirmation_bias

I've been following and digging around this "97% consensus" thing ever since it began, and myself found it could only be better described as a "100% nonsensus". The only reason the surveys by activists were conducted on people was so they could "create" a consensus as they already know people, whether "scientists" or not, have inherent biases. So fk asking erroneous, unqualified, likely highly biased and emotional mammals what they think , let's ask the data that's been around longer than the climate panic and therefore unbiased:

http://www.globalwarming-sowhat.com/_Media/600-my-of-temps-560-my-of_med_hr.jpeg

CO2 was some 15x higher in the past and never a runaway greenhouse. Temps were also some 10C higher than today. CO2 and temperature in general have little to no correlation. Looking back at the cooling from the 40's to the 70's, CO2 was also rising at the time. The panic over a "catastrophic" 1.5C rise by the year 2100 is just a massive lie and yet another goalpost to be shifted, considering temp shifts of the past were much larger and arrived much faster, both up and down. The planet goes through glacial/interglacial cycling about every 100k years, likely due to one of the Milankovitch cycles giving us greater solar insolation and therefore an interglacial:

http://cdn.antarcticglaciers.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/Vostok_420ky_4curves_insolation_to_2004.jpg

Our current Holocene interglacial, which climate scientologists are enjoying with us now but in a panic over, has seen a 10k year downward trend:

https://i.pinimg.com/originals/c8/da/26/c8da26068accf8e8e0538f5d14d019ff.jpg

CO2 levels seem to track the interglacials well, but on closer inspection lag temp changes by some 800 years. This is also likely for CH4 levels since the land and oceans need to warm before they can outgas CH4 and CO2 respectively:

http://joannenova.com.au/2009/12/carbon-rises-800-years-after-temperatures
http://joannenova.com.au/global-warming-2/ice-core-graph

Water vapour is by far the most powerful "greenhouse" gas and blocks much of the CO2 IR absorption bands:

https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405844018327415-gr1.jpg

Dr Robson doesn’t understand scientific process (or chooses to misrepresent it).
 
There are “ideas that all scientists agree on that birds are descended from dinosaurs” … I am a zoologist and this statement is not a straightforward one—it is really important in understanding the process of science. You have to accept Darwin’s Theory of Natural Selection to accept that birds descended from dinosaurs. NOTE it is a THEORY. ​@Steve Wilson First of all, it's absolutely not the case that all circuits can be analyzed in terms of R, L and C. If it were, circuit simulation software (which is much better developed than atmosphere simulation software) would be 100% accurate 100% of the time, and it's not. Diodes, transistors and much more besides exhibit various different non-linear effects and that means that for any analog system, you'd be crazy to make commercial decisions based on simulations only. You have to build a prototype and observe it. Now, when you said "we hold all other variable still and see what diff adding CO2 makes" - you have inadvertently outlined the central problem in all this. We _can't_ fix variables in the real atmosphere. We can fix their values in a simulation, but the result of the simulation may not match reality at all, and the fact that the real temperature curve keeps barely clinging to the bottom range of the IPCC's predictions, even with all the highly dubious 'help' they have given their datasets, strongly suggests to me that the simulations are not at all reflective of reality. That and the fact that CO2 is not seen to lead temperature in the paleo record. Coming on to the tipping point idea - that is pure speculation. The Earth has been significantly warmer than it is today (also, CO2 has been much higher long ago) - and the planet didn't burn up, so I can't see the justification for that hypothesis. Again, I am not advocating doing nothing, or staying with dirty energy tech, or increasing CO2 indefinitely. I think all of those would be terrible mistakes. I just don't believe the current scenario of imminent climate disaster that's being marketed to us so forcefully that even to ask why we're using downward-adjusted historical temp readings rather than raw data is seen as a form of blasphemy.

@Steve Wilson If you are referring to Arrhenius' original paper on the greenhouse effect, that was over 120 years ago, not 70. While it was certainly a seminal work, it is not reasonable to expect any one equation (or set of equations) to properly describe the behaviour of a highly complex system in which multiple other processes are going on. Ohm's Law makes a good analogy. Is it true? Yes. Is it vital to the analysis and design of circuits? Yes. On its own, can it get anywhere near describing the behaviour of modern circuits? No it cannot. Ice melt is a symptom of warming. The planet has been warming ever since the little ice age about 250 years ago. The trend for the earth's surface temperature for the last ~20 years has been flat, meaning the ups basically balance the downs. What you're seeing from the ice melts is from a few years of ups. Climate is about a long term trend, not just what you see in your own lifetime. As for Australia's bushfires, the extent and ferocity is widely acknowledged as a result of leaving the fuel unchecked for over 10 years, whereas previously this was managed with controlled hazard reduction.

Keep looking. The 97% fallacy is ultimately from Cook et al., and it's not 97% at all! It's 97% of the 34% of the papers *and articles* chosen for review, which took a position on AGW, rejecting the 66% of papers which illustrated no position in the abstract. Worse, not all of the papers chosen for review were climate-science papers, and not all of which were peer-reviewed. Worse still, Cook et al., didn't even read the papers themselves -- they perused _only_ the abstracts, most of which in fact took no position at all.

@Fringe Dweller The Y2K issue was not a fake alarm, it was a real threat to the behaviour of computer systems when the date rolled over from 1999 to 2000. Since lots of critical systems only stored the year in 2 digits, there was a risk that 99 would roll over to 00 and thus be seen by code as going back in time, therefore affecting computer logic. When the issue was raised several years before 1999, computer programmers rewrote the code to cater for that risk. I know, I was one of them. Nothing to do with gullibility or false alarm, unlike the political climate hysteria.

Scientists are just as flawed and venal as the population at large, so the notion that science is pure and disinterested is a fallacy. As to CO2, it works in a similar way to water in a microwave oven, in that it is resonant (and thus absorbs and re-radiates heat energy) at frequencies in the microwave bands, but the foremost scientist in the CO2 Radiative Transfer field (a Princeton professor no less) is very sceptical of CO2 having an unlimited warming capacity. CO2 has only a relatively narrow absorption bandwidth, while H2O has a far broader absorption bandwidth, there is a lot more of it, and goes semi-opaque when it condenses, reflecting incoming radiation back into space. CO2 doesn't generally condense, if only because it is not present in sufficient density in the atmosphere (~400ppm). This is physics, not chemistry, although most chemistry is applied physics... Anyway, plenty of room for dispute about CO2 and its effects, rather than it being settled.

One other mdetail that the polls don't address is to limit the participation to people who have the background and experience to be able to attribute where the warming is coming from and to ask questions that have enough nuance to be able to distinguish policy relevant warming.

Cox was commenting on the approach used in the surveys and that does not need expertise in the subject. I believe that setting up a survey to get a policy-relevant answer is hard. Think about what question you would ask. The questions have to determine if changing mankind's CO2 emissions would make a big enough difference on climate-related impacts to justify the costs. The impacts are risk assessments and that adds another layer of complexity. It is a wicked problem! My point in the initial reply was that even if you come up with good survey questions, there are a limited number of scientists with the background and experience to be able to answer those questions independently and justify their answers. There are a larger number but still relatively small number of people who can understand the answers to be able to favor one opinion over another. The problem I have with many of these surveys is that there is no qualification to limit participation to those people who have slogged through the background information so we can trust their answer. Thinking outside the box is fine but if you don't understand the box then your answer is a guess.
